poem:
"Politics in Morning Light"

Politics sneaks into morning's paper,
Labour's triumph spelled in ink.
A dance of reassurance, perhaps a caper,
into the centre-right, they sink.

Moderate policies, gory and glorious,
seem closer to Tory in this tale,
Oh, politics, you're uproarious,
blowing as changeable as the gale.

Beneath the headline's screaming tone,
still a way to go, we glean,
Triumphant Starmer – yet alone,
in the morning's newsprint sheen.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Labour can be proud of its local election results, but there’s still a way to go | Letters Keir Starmer’s party has not only, as Jonathan Freedland says, sought “to reassure Tory switchers” that they have nothing to worry about, in doing so it has remoulded itself into a centre-right conservative Labour party, with policies so moderate that they’re in danger of Tory adoption prior to the election (Triumphant Starmer already seems like the prime". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
